Notes: Federal basic rate. First bracket: 15% on taxable income up to $57,375. Basic Personal Amount (BPA) for 2025 is $16,129 — effectively makes the first $16,129 tax-free via a non-refundable credit of $16,129 x 15% = $2,419. The BPA is income-tested: begins clawback at $177,882 and reduces to $14,538 for income above $253,414. All federal brackets are indexed annually to CPI inflation.
Federal second bracket: 20.5% on taxable income from $57,376 to $114,750.
Federal third bracket: 26% on taxable income from $114,751 to $158,468.
Federal fourth bracket: 29% on taxable income from $158,469 to $220,000.
Federal top bracket: 33% on taxable income above $220,000. This bracket was introduced in 2016 and the $220,000 threshold has remained fixed (not indexed).
Ontario first bracket: 5.05% on taxable income up to $51,446. Ontario basic personal amount for 2025 is $11,865. Ontario brackets are indexed annually to Ontario CPI.
Ontario second bracket: 9.15% on taxable income from $51,447 to $102,894.
Ontario third bracket: 11.16% on taxable income from $102,895 to $150,000.
Ontario fourth bracket: 12.16% on taxable income from $150,001 to $220,000.
Ontario top bracket: 13.16% on taxable income above $220,000.

Ontario Surtax: No surtax when basic Ontario tax (before surtax) is $4,991 or less. The surtax is calculated on basic provincial tax payable (not on income). It adds 20% of basic Ontario tax exceeding $4,991 PLUS 36% of basic Ontario tax exceeding $6,387. Both components apply simultaneously when tax is high enough. This effectively increases top marginal rates for high earners.

Ontario Surtax component 1: 20% of basic Ontario provincial tax exceeding $4,991. Applies when basic provincial tax is between $4,992 and $6,387 (only the 20% component). NOTE: Income_Bracket_Lower/Upper here represent PROVINCIAL TAX amounts, not income amounts. The tool must first calculate basic Ontario tax, then apply surtax on the tax amount.

Ontario Surtax both components: 20% of basic Ontario tax exceeding $4,991 PLUS 36% of basic Ontario tax exceeding $6,387. Combined incremental rate on the tax amount above $6,387 is 56% (20% + 36%). NOTE: brackets here are PROVINCIAL TAX amounts, not income. For income above ~$150,000, both surtax components apply.

Ontario Health Premium: $0 for income up to $20,000. The Ontario Health Premium (OHP) is a separate levy calculated on taxable income. It is NOT part of the income tax bracket system — it is a stepped premium based on income. Unlike marginal tax, the premium uses a specific formula within each income range. Collected through the personal income tax return.
Ontario Health Premium: 6% of income above $20,000 up to a maximum of $300. At $25,000 income: premium = 6% x ($25,000 - $20,000) = $300. Formula: min(6% x (income - $20,000), $300).
Ontario Health Premium: $300 for income $25,001-$36,000 (flat amount in this range).
Ontario Health Premium: $450 for income $38,501-$48,000 (flat amount in this range).
Ontario Health Premium: $600 for income $48,601-$72,000 (flat amount in this range).
Ontario Health Premium: $750 for income $72,601-$200,000 (flat amount in this range).
Ontario Health Premium: $750 + 25% of income above $200,000, up to a maximum of $900/year. At $200,600+: premium caps at $900. Maximum annual premium is $900.
British Columbia first bracket: 5.06% on taxable income up to $47,937. BC basic personal amount for 2025 is $12,580. BC brackets are indexed annually to BC CPI.
British Columbia second bracket: 7.7% on taxable income from $47,938 to $95,875.
British Columbia third bracket: 10.5% on taxable income from $95,876 to $110,076.
British Columbia fourth bracket: 12.29% on taxable income from $110,077 to $133,664.
British Columbia fifth bracket: 14.7% on taxable income from $133,665 to $181,232.
British Columbia sixth bracket: 16.8% on taxable income from $181,233 to $252,752.
British Columbia top bracket: 20.5% on taxable income above $252,752.

Alberta first bracket: 10% on taxable income up to $148,269. Alberta basic personal amount for 2025 is $21,003. Alberta reindexed its brackets to inflation starting in 2022 after a freeze from 2019-2021.
Alberta second bracket: 12% on taxable income from $148,270 to $177,922.
Alberta third bracket: 13% on taxable income from $177,923 to $237,230.
Alberta fourth bracket: 14% on taxable income from $237,231 to $355,845.
Alberta top bracket: 15% on taxable income above $355,845.

Quebec first bracket: 14% on taxable income up to $51,780. Quebec basic personal amount for 2025 is $18,056. Quebec has its own tax collection system (Revenu Quebec) separate from CRA. Quebec residents file both federal and provincial returns. IMPORTANT: Quebec residents receive a 16.5% federal tax abatement — the federal tax payable is reduced by 16.5% to account for Quebec collecting its own income tax.
Quebec second bracket: 19% on taxable income from $51,781 to $103,545.
Quebec third bracket: 24% on taxable income from $103,546 to $126,000.

Quebec top bracket: 25.75% on taxable income above $126,000. Quebec has the highest combined marginal tax rate in Canada at the top bracket (33% federal + 25.75% provincial - 16.5% abatement on federal = approximately 53.3% combined top rate).

INFORMATION ROW — Quebec Federal Tax Abatement. Quebec residents receive a 16.5% reduction on basic federal tax payable. This is because Quebec is the only province that collects its own income tax. Calculation: Federal_Tax_After_Abatement = Federal_Tax x (1 - 0.165). This effectively reduces all federal marginal rates by 16.5% for Quebec residents (e.g., the 15% federal rate becomes ~12.525% effective).
Manitoba first bracket: 10.8% on taxable income up to $47,000. Manitoba basic personal amount for 2025 is $15,780.
Manitoba second bracket: 12.75% on taxable income from $47,001 to $100,000.
Manitoba top bracket: 17.4% on taxable income above $100,000.

Canada Pension Plan (CPP): No contributions on earnings up to the basic exemption of $3,500. CPP applies to all provinces EXCEPT Quebec (which has QPP). CPP is a mandatory payroll deduction for employed and self-employed individuals aged 18-70.

CPP employee contribution rate: 5.95% on pensionable earnings between $3,500 (basic exemption) and $71,300 (YMPE — Year's Maximum Pensionable Earnings for 2025). Maximum employee CPP contribution for 2025 = ($71,300 - $3,500) x 5.95% = $4,034.10. Employer matches this amount. Self-employed pay both portions (11.90%).

CPP2 (Second Additional CPP): 4% employee contribution on earnings between the first ceiling ($71,300 YMPE) and the second ceiling ($79,400 YAMPE — Year's Additional Maximum Pensionable Earnings for 2025). Maximum CPP2 employee contribution = ($79,400 - $71,300) x 4% = $324. CPP2 was introduced in 2024 as part of the CPP enhancement. Employer also contributes 4%.

Quebec Pension Plan (QPP): No contributions on earnings up to the basic exemption of $3,500. QPP applies ONLY to Quebec residents. Same structure as CPP but administered by Retraite Quebec with a higher contribution rate.

QPP employee contribution rate: 6.40% on pensionable earnings between $3,500 and $71,300 (same YMPE as CPP). Maximum employee QPP contribution for 2025 = ($71,300 - $3,500) x 6.40% = $4,339.20. QPP rate is higher than CPP (6.40% vs 5.95%) because Quebec enhanced its pension plan ahead of the federal CPP enhancement. Employer matches this amount.

QPP2 (Second Additional QPP): 4% employee contribution on earnings between $71,300 and $79,400. Same rate and thresholds as CPP2. Maximum QPP2 employee contribution = ($79,400 - $71,300) x 4% = $324. Employer also contributes 4%.

Employment Insurance (EI) employee premium: 1.64% on insurable earnings up to $65,700 (Maximum Insurable Earnings for 2025). Maximum annual employee EI premium = $65,700 x 1.64% = $1,077.48. Applies to all provinces EXCEPT Quebec, which has a reduced rate because Quebec has its own parental insurance plan (QPIP/RQAP). Employer pays 1.4x the employee rate (2.296%). No basic exemption for EI — contributions start from dollar one.

EI employee premium for Quebec residents: 1.31% (reduced rate) on insurable earnings up to $65,700. Maximum annual employee EI premium for Quebec = $65,700 x 1.31% = $860.67. Quebec residents pay a lower EI rate because they contribute separately to the Quebec Parental Insurance Plan (QPIP/RQAP), which covers maternity and parental benefits that EI covers in other provinces. QPIP employee premium is an additional ~0.494% on insurable earnings up to $94,000.
